 This does not make sense to me. The Constitution protects minorities in three ways: First, it spells out the powers of the government, and any powers invoked by the government that are not listed in the Constitution are unconstitutional. This means that since the Constitution does not list many powers of the government to take away freedoms, the government does not have that power. Second, it lists specific rights held by all individuals that the government is not entitled to take away. This includes freedom of speech, religion, the right to bear arms, the right to a fair trial to determine a crime, and others, each of which protect the behavior of individuals. Third, all governmental power is not given directly to the majority; it is dampened because officials must make decisions, it is an indirect power. The most prominant protection for minorities comes in the form of the judicial system, which is neither elected by the majority or held accountable to the majority or mob-rule in any fashion. Certainly the judicial system is able and intended to protect the minority when the majority is annoyed with their behavior.
 
 
Since we are a republic then representatives vote on our behalf.

The only reasonable argument I have heard which suggests that this might be the case is that a child needs to learn from the experiences of both genders, for each gender holds a different role in society. Yet this argument is flawed in that teaching a child which role each gender holds in society limits that child's potential only to those roles, and I do not see how this can somehow be construed as a good thing.
 
 Even if there were a way to prove which set of parents were optimal, it would make absolutely no sense to deny marriage to the group less optimal. What if it were that same-sex parents are more optimal than opposite-sex parents? Does it then make sense to deny marriage benefits to opposite-sex parents? What if it could be shown that Muslim parents are more optimal than Christian parents? Would it then make sense to deny marriage to Christian parents. What if it could be shown that black parents are more optimal than white parents? Surely one must be more optimal than the other in every case. We've seen that same-sex couples are capable of raising children well, and it is not now and never has been the place of the government to benefit it's preferred type of family over its less preferred type. Same-sex parents have the same needs as opposite-sex parents, and that's the bottom line; to deny them benefits is to promote the majority lifestyle over the minority.
